comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Perhaps Victor Castro as reported on August 4, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A07E6DD113CE633A...

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: It is likely Cipriano Castro, ex-president of Venezuela, who is mentioned in the article swanq found about Victor Castro. Searching the Prints & Photographs Online Catalog ("PPOC") ( www.loc.gov/rr/print/catalog.html ), I found another image of Castro in New York--a photo the Library of Congress acquired after it was deposited for copyright in Feb. 1913 (see: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3a48090 ). It looks to be the same man, and there he is identified as Cipriano, the ex-president. An additional image that shows his face better is: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/cph.3c00798 . He is also featured in a couple of cartoons in PPOC. Cipriano Castro apparently arrived in New York early in 1913 (see: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9D03E... ). We'll add some identifying information to both this image and a related image, flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3047667193/ Thanks for getting the identification ball rolling!

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Former dictator of Venezuela (1899-1908), the deposed tyrant, General Cipriano Castro, attempted a U. S. visit in January, 1913, but was detained at Ellis Island in quarantine. That is when this photo and its companion were taken, by the Bain News Agency. Apparently he was let in, however, and as a private citizen attended the inauguration of U. S. President Woodrow Wilson in Washington, D.C., on March 4, 1913. In 1916, Castro was again detained at Ellis Island when he attempted to land at New York while en route from Trinidad to Porto {Puerto} Rico. Story in New York Times, July 17, 1916: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C03E3D9173BE6...
